bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

body.head: Sacred Stories 07: Wisahketchahk as a Captain

p.seg: kîtahtawê êsah sa-sipwêhtêw ; ayisk misiwê kîh-tôtam wîsahkêcâhk . Once upon a time he went from place to place; for Wisahketchahk did all kinds of things.
ahpôh kî-kaskihtâw êh-onôtinikêwokimâwit . He even managed to become a captain of soldiers.
kêtahtawê sipwêhtêw êsah . Once upon a time, the story goes, he set out.
â , papamohtêw . Well, he tramped about.

kîtahtawê wâskahikan kâh-ôtihtahk . Presently he came to a wooden house. LB on {wâskahikan}: Properly “stockade”; used of the trading-post forts, and of white men's houses generally. This is the first of many foreign features in this tale: Wisahketchahk is here among white people.

seg.gloss: “Ha, stay a while, stay a while, big brother!”

p.seg: êkwah tapwêh apiw êsah . So he stayed there.
ntônikêyiwa iskwêwa , êw-asamikot . A woman looked for something to give him to eat.
hôh , namwâc kêkway wâpahtam kit-ôtinamiyit mîciwin . Ho, he saw nothing at all in the way of food that she could take.
sôskwâc tâpiskwêkanêkinwah otinêyiwa , ota mîcisowinâhtikohk êsiwêpinâyit . At once she took out a shawl and threw it on the table.
wâpahtam êkotah nanâtohk mîciwinah . There he saw all kinds of food.

mâka mîna itêyihtam wîsahkêcâhk ;
nka-kimotin , itêyihtam . In his usual way, Wisahketchahk thought, “I shall steal it,” he thought.
mâ-mitonêyihtam tânisi t-êsi-nôhtê-nipâyit ôhi ka-pê-kîwokawât . He kept revolving in his mind how he could make his hostesses want to sleep.

ômis îtwêw :
hâw , kiyawâw , nisîmitik , nêwo-tipiskâw kik-âcimostâtinâwâw . He said, “Now, in return, my little sisters, for four nights I will tell you stories.”
hâ , tâpwê , nistêsê , nimiywêyihtênân êh-âcimohk ! itik ôhih iskwêwah . “Oh, indeed, big brother, we like story-telling!” those women said to him.
nama wîhkâc wâpamêw ta-kîsitêpowit . He never saw them do any cooking.

nika-kimotamawâw , nipâcih , otâpiskâkanêkinwah , êy-itêyihtahk êsah wîsahkêcâhk , êkwah âcimôw kapê-tipisk . “When she goes to sleep, I shall steal her shawl from her,” thought Wisahketchahk, and told stories all night.
namoya ôhci nipâyiwa . But they did not go to sleep.
âsay mîna kapê-kîsik âcimôw . All the next day he told stories.
kîhtwâm mîna êh-tipiskâyik , âsay mîna kêyâpic namwâc nipâyiwa . When another night came, again they did not sleep at all.

seg.gloss: “Could it be that I should be unable to steal it from them!”

p.seg: mwêhci nêo-tipiskâw êh-âcimot , êkoyikohk nipâyiwa ôhi oskinîkiskwêwa . When he had told stories for exactly four nights and days, then those young women went to sleep.
ntonikêw otasiwacikaniyihk ; kimotamawêw . He searched where they kept their things; he stole it from them.
êkos îsi sipwêhtayimêw ; tapasîw . So then he went off with it; he fled.
nêwo-tipiskâw pimipahtâw . For four days and nights he ran.
êkwah kîtahtawê kâ-pêhtahk ê-matwê-cîkahikêwiht . Then at one time he heard someone noisily chopping wood.
ohcitaw kik-ôtihtitin , itêyihtam êsah . “I shall do my best to reach you,” he thought.
êkwah sipwêhtêw . Then he went on.
âsay mîna êh-wâpaniyik , âhci piko pêhtam . When the next day broke, he still heard it.

êkwah piyisk nêwo-tipiskâw tâpiskôc pêyakwan iyikohk ê-matwê-cîkahikêyit , nêwo-tipiskâw mwêhci ê-pmohtêt , êkoyikohk wâpamêw kîkisêp , ê-matwê-wâskahikanihkêyit . And at last, when he had heard the other chopping away for four days and nights, apparently always at the same distance, and when he had walked four days and nights, then at last, in the morning, he saw him, noisily working at a wooden structure.
namwâc kêkway wâpahtam kita-osîhtayit mihtah , âta nêwo-kîsikâw êh-pêhtahk . He saw no wood at all with which that person could build anything, though he had heard the noise of it for four days.
nîso piko mihtah kiyastêyiwa . Only two sticks lay there.

seg.q: wâh , nisîm , kayâs ohci , nêwo-tipiskâw aspin , kâ-pêhtamân ê-nikohtêyin !
seg.gloss: “Dear me, little brother, for a long time, ever since four nights ago, I have heard you chopping!”

p.seg: êh-âtah-kitôtât , namwâc ahpôh wîh-kitâpamik . Although he spoke to him, the other would not so much as glance at him.
kapê-kisik pikw îsi âtah êy-isi-kitôtât , ahpôh namwâc wî-kitâpamik . Although through the day he addressed him in all manner of ways, he would not even look at him.

ntawâc êkwah , ê-wîh-tipiskâyik , aspin êh-astâyit cîkahikaniyiw , êh-âta-nawaswâtât , namoya kiskêyimêw êh-pîhtokêyit . And then, at nightfall, when the other laid down his hatchet and was off and away, he needs ran after him, but he could not make out into what place he had disappeared.
namoya miskawêw ; wanihêw . He could not find him; he had lost him.

misiwê papâmitâcimôw ,
nisîm , kikitimahin ! êh-papây-itwêt , êh-papâmitâcimot , ê-wîh-kakwê-ka-kitotikot , êh-ntawêyihtahk ta-kitotikot . He crawled about, and, “Little brother, you are making me desperate!” he kept crying, to make the other speak to him; desiring to have the other address him.
piyisk êtokê nêstohkwasiw . At last he must have gotten sleepy from weariness.
kawîhkwasiw . He fell, overcome by sleep.
sâsay mîna kayahtê êh-waniskât , kî-nâ-nâtwâyinihtêyiwa . When he awoke, there was the other already a-splitting of logs.

âsay mîna kapê-kîsik âta ,
nisîm ! pikw îsi êh-ât-îtât , nama wîh-ka-kitotik . Again, though all day he kept saying to him, “Little brother!” he would not talk to him.

âsay mîna ê-tipiskâyik , aspin ât ê-kîwêyit , ati-miciminêw ; êh-ati-pîhtokêyit wîkiyihk , êkotah ohci wanihêw . When the next night came, when the other made off to go home, he held fast to him, but when he went into his dwelling, from that point he lost him.
âsay mîna kapê-tipisk papâmitâcimôw , ê-ntonawât ; Again he crawled about all night, looking for him;
piyisk mîna mohcihk êkosi isi nipâw . at last he again slept right there on the bare ground.
kîkisêpâ êh-waniskât , âsay mîna kîh-nikohtêyiwa mîna kîhtwâm . In the morning, when he got up, this time, too, the other had already started working at his wood.
anohc êkwah ôhcitaw kika-kitosin ! itêyihtam êsa mâka mîna wîsahkêcâhk . “Now today I will see to it that you talk to me!” thought Wisahketchahk as before.
âsay mîna kapê-kîsik âta êh-kitotât , nama ki-kitotik . Again, though he talked to him all day, he could not make the other address him.
âsay mîna ati-kîwêyiwa . Again the other went home.
mistahi êkwah pakwâtam . He was very much annoyed.
kisisin . He landed on something sharp.
âhpoh ôm ! îtêyihtam ; “Maybe it is this!” he thought; LB on {âhpoh ôm}: Meaning not clear; record may be wrong.

seg.gloss: “Surely he is at home here!

p.seg: cîpay êkâ kâ-wîh-ka-kitosit ! itêyihtam êsah . He is a dead man, this person who will not converse with me!” he thought.
tâpwê mâhtakoskam oskan , êkotah ê-miskahk . Accordingly, he threw his weight on that bone and held it down.

êkwah kîkisêpâ kayâhtê êh-pêkopayit ,
awas , wîsahkêcâhk ! kôtamihin ! nimiywêyihtêh êh-cîkahikêyân ! k-êtikot , kayâhtê ê-mâtakoskawât . Then, in the morning he was awakened by the other saying to him, “Get away Wisahketchahk! You are keeping me back! I was having a pleasant time at chopping!” for he was holding him down by the weight of his body.
cêskwa , nisîm ! itêw ; “Wait a bit, little brother!” he told him;

seg.q: nisîm , mistahi kikakwâtakihin , âta nêo-kîsikâw êh-kitotitân , êkâ êh-kitosiyin .
seg.gloss: “Little brother, you were tormenting me terribly, by not talking to me, when for four days I addressed you.”

seg.q: tânêhki mâka êkâ kêkway k-ôh-kaskihtâyin , tahkih ê-nikohtêyin tahto-kîsikâw ?
seg.gloss: “But why is it you accomplish nothing, when you are always a-chopping every day?”

p.seg: ôtah kayâs ê-kih-pahkwêkahamân nisit , itik êsah . “It is because of old in this place I chopped off my foot,” the other told him.

seg.gloss: “Do you never eat?”

p.seg: êhag , itwêw awa cîpay ; “No,” said the dead man;
tântêh mâka kîw-ôhtinamân mîciwin ? itêw wîsahkêcâhkwa . “Where could I get any food?” he said to Wisahketchahk.

seg.gloss: “But if you were given something to eat, would you eat?”

p.seg: êhag , nikah-mîcison , kîspin asamiyin , itwêw êsah awa cîpay . “Yes, I would eat, if you gave me food,” said the dead man.

seg.gloss: “Very well, little brother, I shall give you something to eat.”

p.seg: êkwah ôma kâ-kîh-kimotit tâpiskâkanêkin otinam , êh-taswêkiwêpinahk . Then he took the shawl he had stolen and spread it out.

atôspowinâhtikohk pôtih kahkiyaw kêkway wâpahtam . Look you, on a table he saw all kinds of things. LB on {atôspowinâhtikohk}: The ordinary term is {mîcisôwinâhtik}; the word in the text resembles Ojibwa {adôhpôwin}; Cree {atôspôw}, Ojibwa {adôhpp}: “he eats on something,” initial stem {atôt-}: “on something,” transitive verb final {-pw-}: “by mouth,” with the middle-voice verb derivative {-ô-}.
tânispihk êtokê ômîcisohtay awa cîpay ! I wonder when that corpse had last eaten!
ayisk wîsahkêcâhk k-êsiyîhkâsot kahkiyaw awiya kîh-wayêsimêw . For he who was called Wisahketchahk deceived everyone.
mistahi nâspic atamihêw êh-asamât . He entirely won him over by giving him the food.

seg.q: hâ , mistahi kitatamihin , wîsahkêcâhk , ôma k-âsamiyan !
seg.gloss: “Hah, you greatly oblige me, Wisahketchahk, giving me food like this!”
seg.note: LB on {kitatamihin}: Literally, “You delight me,” the usual formula of thanks.

p.seg:
hâ , nisim , itêw ,
niya nipapâmâcihon . “Oh, little brother,” he told him, “as for me, I am travelling about.

seg.gloss: I shall not have any use for this shawl.

p.seg: kiya nama nântaw ka-kîh-ohtinamâson ta-mîciyin , itêw ôhi cîpaya . But you would not have any resource from which to get anything to eat,” he told the dead man.

êhag , itwêw awa cîpay ,
mistahi kitatamihin , wîsahkêcâhk ! “Yes,” said the dead man, “I thank you very much, Wisahketchahk!

seg.gloss: Now I shall never be hungry, Wisahketchahk.

p.seg: mahtih nimistikôwâtihk osâwi-sôniyâw êkotah miskawacih , otinâhkan , itwêw awa cîpay . Go see; if you find any gold in my wooden box, just take it,” said the corpse.
tâpwê wîsahkêcâhk ê-sîhkimiht , ntonikêw osâwi-sôniyâwa . According [sic] as he was bidden, Wisahketchahk looked for gold.

seg.q: wîsahkêcâhk , kakwê-iyinisih mâka ! âta wiyah kimôhcôwin .
seg.gloss: “But, Wisahketchahk, be sensible! After all, you are a crazy fellow.

seg.q: ôtah kwêski-sakâhk namoya wâhyaw okimâw mêkwâh kwâpahwêw sôniyâwa .
seg.gloss: At the other side of these woods a chief is now digging gold.
You will go where he is.
You will go see him.

seg.q:
ômisi kik-êtâw :
niyanân tâpwê miyosiw kâ-kwâpahwâyâhk osâwi-sôniyâw , kik-êtâw ;
seg.gloss: You will say to him, ‘The gold we others are digging is really fine,’ you will say to him;
‘Yours is very poor.
You are scooping up almost nothing but water,’ you will say to him;
‘But as for us others, I scoop up pure gold,’ you will say to him;

q.q: êkwah kiya kêkâc pisisik nipiy kikwâpahên .

seg.gloss: ‘And you, you are scooping up almost nothing but water.

seg.q: nawac itah sôniyâw k-ôhtinak kîstah pêy-itohtêyin , kik-êtâw .
seg.gloss: You had better come over yourself to where I get gold,’ you will tell him.
And when you have led him far off, you will kill him.

seg.q: k-êsinâkosit awa okimâw , êkosi nika-wîh-sinâkosin ! kik-êtwân .
seg.gloss: ‘As the chief looked, so I shall look!’ you will say.
Then you will resemble him completely.”

p.seg: êkosi sipwêhtêw , ê-kîh-kakêskimikot wîsahkêcâhk ôhi cîpayah , êkwah okimâwa ê-wîh-ntawi-nipahât . Then Wisahketchahk set out, as he had been directed by the dead man, to go and kill that chief.
tâpwêh namoya wâhyaw êy-itohtêt , sîpîsis otihtam , ê-mêkwâ-kwâpahwâyit sôniyâwa . And really, he had not gone far, when he came to a brook where the latter was digging for gold.
tâpwê kiya mistahi mâyâtisiw sôniyâw ka-kwâpahwat , itwêw wîsahkêcâhk ; “Truly, the metal you are digging up is very poor,” Wisahketchahk told him;

seg.gloss: “But our metal is very fine;
we get nothing but gold.”

p.seg: tântê mâka mahtih ? itik ; “Now, where is that, pray?” the other asked him;

seg.gloss: “Take me there.

p.seg: mahti nka-ntawâpahtên , itik . Let me go see it,” he told him.
kêkwah âh wâpahtêhêw . He showed him some. CHECK âh - heavy redup? DON'T KNOW
nînân osâwi-sôniyâw pikoh nôtinânân , itik . “We get nothing but gold,” he told him.
itah êh-âyimaniyik atih-ay-itohtahêw . he led him on into rough places.

êkwah wâhyaw êh-ayâcik , mistikwah nîso êh-cimasoyit , êkotah ê-sêkoyit , ostikwâniyihk pakamahwêw ; nipahêw . Then, when they had gone quite a ways, as the other got between two trees that stood close, he hit him on the head and killed him.
êkosi nka-wîh-naspitawâw awa okimâw ! itwêw êsah wîsahkêcâhk . “So now I want to resemble this chief!” said Wisahketchahk.
tâpwê , ayisk wîcihik ôhi cîpayah ; tâpwê naspitawêw êsah ôhi okimâwa . And really, for he was being helped by that Deadman, really, he looked exactly like the chief.

seg.gloss: “Now I shall go straight home.

p.seg: mahtih êsinâkosiyit wîwah , itêyihtam . Let me see what his wife looks like,” he thought.
aciyaw piko kwâpahwêw sôniyâwa . He dug for gold but for a short while.
wawêyîw ; êkos îsi kîwêw . He dressed up; right then he went home.
wâhyaw ohci pêcâpamik ôhi kâ-nipahât wîwiyiwa . From afar the wife of him whom he had killed saw him coming.

seg.q: tânisi k-ôh-pê-kîwêyin nama wîhkâc nôhtaw kipê-kîwân .
seg.gloss: “Why are you coming home? You never come home before the regular time.
It is always twelve o'clock that you come home to eat dinner.
You are acting very crazily, all of a sudden!”

p.seg: âta wiyah êsa nisitohtawêw . He did somehow understand what she was saying.
êkwah êkos îsi kîwêw . So he went right back.
mîna ntaw-itohtêw . He went back where he had come from.
aciyaw pêy-ôtihtik ôhi kâ-kî-kiskinôhamâkot cîpayah . Soon the Deadman who had instructed him came to where he was.

seg.gloss: “Certainly you will soon get yourself killed!
It is evident that you will act too crazily!

p.seg: namwâc ahpôh kikiskêyimâw pîsimohkân ! itik . You do not even know the clock!” he told him.
êkwah wâpamêw pîsimohkâna , êkoyâk kâ-nisitawêyimât . Then he looked at a clock, making his first acquaintance with it.
êkwah kîwêw , nîsosâp tipahikan êy-ispayiyik . Then he went home, when twelve o'clock had come.
âsay mîna ntaw-âtoskêw , min ê-ntawâpamât sôniyâwa . Then he went back to work, to look for gold.
êkwah wîpac pôn-atoskêw . He quite work after a short time.

tâpwê kîtahtawê mistahi kimôhcôwin , itik ôhi owîkimâkanah ,
êkwah wâh-wîpac êh-pê-kîwêyin ! itik . “Really, all of a sudden you have gone altogether insane,” that wife of his said to him, “Coming home early all the time like this!”

hâh , ômis îtwêw ;
kîtahtawê wâ-wîpac kêkway niwâh-wani-kiskisin , itwêw . “Why,” he said, “my memory has become very short, all of a sudden.”
êkw êh-otâkosiniyik , masinahikan kâ-pîhtokatâyit . Then, in the evening someone brought in a letter.
namwâc nisitawinam . He could make nothing of it.
kâ-kiskisit anihi cîpayah ka-kîh-kitimâkêyimikot , êkwah wayawîw . Remembering that Deadman who had befriended him, he went out of the house.
wahwa , mistahi kimôhcôwin ! itik ; “Alas, you are a crazy fool!” he told him;

seg.gloss: “And so it appears you will soon be killed!”

p.seg: sâ-sâminamiyiwa ôhkwâkana , oskîsikwa , otôn : nisitawinam masinahikan . The other touched his face, his eyes and his mouth: he could read.
êkwah êh-wâpahtahk , masinahikâtêyiw , wâpahkih ê-wîh-pê-nôtiniht ; Then, when he read it, it was written that tomorrow people were coming to fight him;

ayisk onôtinikêwah ôhi okimâwah kâ-nipahât , êkwah wâh-wîpac êsah mâna êh-pêh-nôtinimiht . for that chief he had killed had been at war, and had been attacked, it seemed, every little while. CHECK - KR {onôtinikêwah} may be a verb, as assumed by LB in his footnote: LB on {onôtinikêwah}: Should be obviative; I may have mis-heard a form {onôtinikêyiwa}, but do not know if such would be the obviative of this preterite. HCW - I'm right.
masinahikêw ; âcimostawêw otînima . He wrote; he told his followers the news.

tâpwê ,
wawêyîk , iyinitik . “Get yourselves ready, men.

seg.gloss: Tomorrow they are coming to fight us.
seg.note: LB on {kiwîh-pê-nôtinikonânaw}: This would seem to mean “he (or it) will come to fight us”; probably read {kiwîh-pê-nôtinikawinânaw}.

p.seg:
nipêyitisahamâkawin , itêw ,
masinahikanah . Letters have been sent to me.”
tâpwê kikisêpâ takohtêyiwa kâ-pêh-ntopayîstâkocik . And really, in the morning they arrived who were coming to make war against them.
mâka wiya wîsahkêcâhk mâka mîna ka-kitâpahkêw kontah . But as for Wisahketchahk, of course, he merely looked on in his useless way. NEW PARAGRAPH

kîtahtawêh ômis îtik ôh îskwêwah :
tâpwê mistahi kimôhcôwin ! Presently that woman said to him, “Truly, you are entirely foolish!

seg.q: kitayôwinisah ta-sîhkihkêmoyan kit-ôtinamihk , ta-posiskaman , mîna kitêm kita-wiyâhpitiht .
seg.gloss: “You ought to order your clothes to be taken out for you to put on, and your horse to be saddled.”

p.seg: tâpwê wîsahkêcâhk sîhkihkêmôw otêmah ta-wiyâhpitimiht . So Wisahketchahk ordered his horse to be saddled.
wiyâhpitimâwa . It was saddled.
postayôwinisêw ; nitawi-nôtinikêw . He put on his clothes; he went and fought.
mistahi mâka mîna môhcôhkâsôw . Of course he carried on in a crazy way.
kahkiyaw êsah mêscihêw ôhi kâ-pê-nôtinikêyit . He killed all those who had come to fight.
êkosi pêyak pikoh kîwêtisahwêw , masinahikan ê-kiw-ôsihtât . He sent only one back home, having written a letter.

nêtêh êh-takohtatâcik , ômis îtwêwak otiyinisiwak :
mâka min êtokê wîsahkêcâhk ! itwêwak . When he arrived over there, the wise men said, “Doubtless this is Wisahketchahk, up to his old tricks!” LB on {êh-takohtatâcik}: Why plural actor? The rest of the story is obscure because the persons are not kept distinct.

masinahikan osîhtaw :
kîspin kiya wîsahkêcâhk , kiwîh-nipahitin sôskwâc . He wrote a letter: “If you are Wisahketchahk, I shall kill you without delay.

seg.gloss: You are cutting up altogether too much.”

p.seg: pôt êkwah êh-pêtamâht wîsahkêcâhk , ayamihtâw . When it was brought to Wisahketchahk he read it.
kiy êtokê mâka mîna , wîsahkêcâhk , ôma kâ-tôtaman , itâw . “Doubtless it is you, Wisahketchahk, up to your old tricks, who are doing all this,” he was told.
namoy âhpôh awiyah wâpahtêhêw ôma masinahikan ; he did not even show anyone this letter;
êkos îsi êy-isih-tapasît . he fled just as he was, at once.
nêo-tipiskâw pimâmôw . He ran four days and nights.
hâw , wîsahkêcâhk , ka-mêtawânânaw ! itik . “Now, Wisahketchahk, let us have a contest!” he said to him.
êkwah tâpwê kakwêcimêw tânisi kit-êsi-mêtawêcik . So he asked him in what way they were to contend.
waskic nipîhk ka-pimohtânânaw , itik . “We shall walk on the surface of the water,” the other told him. NEW PARAGRAPH
êhag , itwêw wîsahkêcâhk . “Very well,” said Wisahketchahk.
tâpwê ati-sipwêhtêw awa wîsahkêcâhkwah kâ-mawinêhwât . Accordingly he started out who had challenged Wisahketchahk.
namwâc ahpô wayiskam nipiy . He did not even ripple the water as he stepped.
akâmihk êh-kîh-takohtêt , êkotê ohci têpwâtêw wîsahkêcâhkwah . When he reached the other side, from there he shouted to Wisahketchahk.

seg.q: haw , mwêhci tâwakâm ayâcih wîsahkêcâhk , êkotah ntawi-kihtâpayiw ;
seg.gloss: “Now, when Wisahketchahk is right in the middle of the water, he will sink under water;
but I do not mean to kill him.
Let him sit down there for good, there in the water!”

p.seg: tâpwêh itâmi-nipîhk êkotê nahapiw , itamihk nipîhk . And really, there he sat down, under water.
kahkiyaw kêkway êh-atotât , nama wiya tâpwêhtâk . When he called every kind of being to help him, they did not heed him.

kahkiyaw ,
nkostânân kâ-tôtask , itik . Everyone told him, “We fear him who is doing this to you.”
kîtahtawê mâkwah kâ-têpêyimot kit-ôtinât wîsahkêcâhkwah . At last the loon consented to take Wisahketchahk from where he was.
otinik êyakonih . He took him out.
êkosi pimâcihik . So he saved his life.
